results.title: Mint tea = Le The la menthe
results.brief_description: A young man sits on the terrace of a Montparnasse cafe, watching the other patrons as they meet friends, enjoy a drink, flirt, or sit waiting. His own loneliness becomes increasingly apparent against this background of other people, with whom he cannot communicate. French language with some English.

results.title: Minoru: memory of exile
results.creator_credit: Bill Pettigrew, ONF | NFB and Michael Fukushima
results.brief_description: With the bombing of the American naval base at Pearl Habour on December 7, 1941, the position of Japanese Canadians was altered dramatically. This is the story of one among the thousands of Japanese families that were affected by a growing atmosphere of racism and rejection that saw Japanese Canadians dispatched to internment camps in the mountains of British Columbia and following the end of the war, given the choice to be deported to Japan, whether it was their birth place or otherwise, or be placed in working groups throughout Canada. Directed by Michael Fukushima, this is a short documentary film interspersed with classical animation and archival material about his father, Minoru, and his experiences, first as a nine year old, of their family’s loss of property, their transferral to internment camps and then attempted resettlement in Japan. With its sensitive reflection on memory and survival and his own relationship with his father, Fukushima’s work continues the study until the Canadian government’s official apology and compensation for loss and suffering in the 1980s and interrogates his own sense of being a Canadian after this time.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Pettigrew, ONF | NFB and Michael Fukushima

results.title: Minority report
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, NBCUniversal, Amblin Entertainment, Blue Tulip, Cruise-Wagner Productions, Jan De Bont, Bonnie Curtis, Gerald Molen, Walter Parkes and Steven Spielberg
results.brief_description: In the near future a scientist (Max Von Sydow) has created a perfect system by which to end murder. By utilising the psychic abilities of “precogs”—three individuals who have been rendered schizophrenic by being born to drug-addicted mothers—he can identify killers before they commit their crimes. The Precrime Unit, led by the zealous John Anderton (Tom Cruise), whose son was abducted years ago, has resulted in the apparent end of homicide in Washington DC. But on the eve of Precrime going national, John Anderton finds himself in an accidental encounter with one of the precogs, Agatha (Samantha Morton), which leads to his name being revealed as a future murderer. With only one day and night in which to prove his “innocence”, Anderton kidnaps Agatha and searches for the true secrets underlying the miracle of Precrime judgement. Based on a short fiction by Philip K. Dick, “Minority Report” is a darkly dystopic vision of the future. Echoing Ridley Scott’s “Blade Runner” in presenting a world divided into enclaves of privilege and vast slums of poverty and crime, the film works best in realistically conveying the architecture, technology and domiciles of a possible future. In this, Spielberg is assisted by state-of-the-art special effects and a wizard art production team. Spielberg’s career-long obsession with reconstituting the nuclear family finally delivers a narrative arc which differs wildly from Dick’s much bleaker vision. But for all his Capraesque desire for closure and hope, what remains with the viewer is the horror of a society which has abrogated to science the role of judgement, and which has therefore nullified the meaning of free will. This two disc special edition of “Minority Report” features a second disc with over an hour of special features. The film also stars Colin Farrell.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, NBCUniversal, Amblin Entertainment, Blue Tulip, Cruise-Wagner Productions, Jan De Bont, Bonnie Curtis, Gerald Molen, Walter Parkes and Steven Spielberg

results.title: Minkey
results.creator_credit: Western Australia Institute of Technology and Peter Goodall
results.brief_description: A promotional video for the sport of “Minkey”, a modified form of hockey and part of the Aussie Sports program. Minkey can be played by combined teams of boys and girls on any flat surface and involves a number of individual and team skills.

results.title: Minister of hate
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin, Kenco Films and CBS News
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Examines the techniques of mass thought control evolved by the brilliant, ruthless Nazi minister, Joseph Goebbels, and shows the dangerous effects which totalitarian control of communications can have on a society. Includes Fritz Lang commenting briefly on his meeting with Goebbels. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Mining: a career for you
results.brief_description: This film provides a look at the career opportunities offered by the mining industry. It shows the Western Australian School of Mines at Kalgoorlie where the student may study for a career in mining, and also reveals some of the field work he will be required to perform in the industry.

results.title: Mining in Australia: the the story of copper
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Government Film Unit and Brian Merrett
results.brief_description: Describes copper mining at Mt Lyell in Tasmania. Shows blasting, crushing of the ore, removal of iron particles, grinding the ore to powder, silo stores, blast furnace, removal of slag, the converter, and finally the cathode copper.

results.title: Mining for copper
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Rank and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: An account of mining and refining of copper in Northern Rhodesia; the geography of the country; details of structure of the mines; operation of the mine; processes for the extraction of copper from ore including the crushing, smelting, refining and final casting into commercial moulds for shipment.
